metadata.title: Severe Asthma Exacerbation
learning_objectives: Recognize deterioration signs including silent chest

changelog.v3.0_enhanced: Blueprint Structure Enhancement v2 applied: matching config for checklist, clinical anchors, consequence templates, ECG standardization. Updated deterioration timing to 5/9/13 min. Removed challenge_points per MVP specification. Duration updated to 20 minutes.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Getting worse, very short of breath

patient_profile.name: Sarah
patient_profile.personality: Anxious, cooperative when able to speak, becomes less responsive as condition worsens

initial.student_sees: You arrive to find a 28-year-old female sitting in a tripod position, leaning forward with hands on knees. She's in obvious severe respiratory distress - you can hear audible wheezing from across the room. She's pale, sweaty, and using her neck and shoulder muscles to breathe. When she tries to speak, she can only manage one or two words at a time before gasping for air. Her roommate looks very worried.
initial.appearance: Patient in tripod position, severe respiratory distress, speaking in words only, using accessory muscles, pale and sweaty
initial.clinical_note: Severe respiratory distress with critical hypoxia (SpO2 88%). Requires immediate oxygen and systematic ABCDE assessment to identify cause. Consider bronchodilators if assessment suggests bronchospasm.

improving.student_sees: The patient appears noticeably more comfortable now. She's still sitting up but no longer in the rigid tripod position. Her breathing, while still faster than normal, is less labored. She can now speak in short phrases instead of just single words. Her color is better - less pale, and she's not as sweaty. She gives you a small nod and manages to say 'feeling... a bit better...'
improving.appearance: Patient more relaxed, breathing easier, can speak in phrases, less accessory muscle use, better color
improving.clinical_note: Positive response to interventions. Respiratory status improving - continue monitoring and treatment. Patient stabilizing but still requires close observation.

deteriorating.student_sees: The patient's condition has worsened significantly. She looks exhausted and is barely able to keep her eyes open. Her lips and fingernails have a bluish tint. When you listen to her chest, it's eerily quiet - you can barely hear any air movement, which is concerning given how hard she's trying to breathe. She's no longer responding clearly to your questions, just weakly nodding or shaking her head.
deteriorating.appearance: Patient exhausted, barely speaking, altered consciousness, cyanotic, silent chest developing
deteriorating.clinical_note: Critical deterioration - worsening respiratory failure despite interventions or due to lack of treatment. Prepare for advanced airway management (BVM, possible intubation). This is pre-arrest state.

critical.student_sees: CRITICAL: The patient is now unresponsive or barely responsive. Her breathing has become very slow and irregular, or she may have stopped breathing altogether. Her skin has a deep blue-gray color. She does not respond to your voice or touch. This is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate action.
critical.appearance: Patient unresponsive or minimally responsive, agonal breathing or apneic, profound cyanosis
critical.clinical_note: Respiratory arrest imminent or occurring. Requires immediate ventilatory support (BVM minimum). Prepare for full resuscitation if progresses to cardiac arrest.

airway.deteriorating: Open but at risk, patient becoming unable to protect airway
airway.critical: At risk, may require BVM or advanced airway

breathing.initial: RR 32, shallow, labored, bilateral decreased air entry with wheeze, silent chest in bases (ominous), intercostal retractions, accessory muscle use
breathing.improving: RR 24, less labored, wheeze improving and louder (good sign - more air moving), less accessory muscle use
breathing.deteriorating: RR 38-40, shallow ineffective breaths, silent chest throughout, exhaustion evident
breathing.critical: RR 6-8 or apneic, agonal breathing, no air movement

circulation.initial: HR 128 regular but weak radial, BP 138/86, CRT <2sec, pale and sweaty
circulation.critical: HR 55 (bradycardia from hypoxia), BP dropping, imminent arrest

disability.initial: GCS 14 (E4 V4 M6), AVPU Alert but distressed, pupils equal and reactive

assessment_findings.exposure: No injuries, no rashes (not anaphylaxis), temperature 37.1°C

sample_history.symptoms: Tight chest, wheezing, can't breathe, getting worse over 2 days
sample_history.allergies: Pollen, dust mites, smoke - no drug allergies
sample_history.medications: Salbutamol inhaler (empty), Fluticasone (ran out 3 days ago)
sample_history.past_history: Asthma since age 8, ICU admission 2 years ago for severe attack
sample_history.last_intake: Small sips water - too breathless to eat
sample_history.events: Cold symptoms 3 days ago, roommate smoking indoors, ran out of controller inhaler

assessment_findings.chest_examination: Hyperresonant percussion, decreased air entry bilaterally, expiratory wheeze throughout, silent chest in lower zones - concerning sign
assessment_findings.chief_complaint_detail: Patient struggles to speak: 'Can't... breathe... getting... worse...' Roommate reports patient has been deteriorating for 2 days, much worse last hour

other_findings: Right axis deviation (common in severe asthma from lung hyperinflation)
Low voltage QRS in limb leads
P pulmonale (peaked P waves in II, III, aVF)

interpretation.diagnosis: Sinus tachycardia with signs of right heart strain
interpretation.mechanism: Compensatory response to hypoxia and increased pulmonary resistance
interpretation.note: FOR AGENT REFERENCE ONLY - Not shown to students during scenario

ecg_findings.teaching_point: ECG in severe asthma typically shows sinus tachycardia as compensatory response to hypoxia. Right heart strain signs (right axis, P pulmonale) indicate increased pulmonary vascular resistance from bronchospasm. ECG is NOT indicated as primary tool in asthma - focus on clinical assessment and bronchodilator therapy. ECG confirms no cardiac cause for symptoms.
ecg_findings.note: Visual ECG display planned for future release

salbutamol.mechanism: Relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle via beta-2 receptor stimulation

dosing.frequency: Can repeat every 20 minutes or continuous nebulization in severe cases

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: That's helping... I can breathe easier...
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Bronchodilation, improved air entry, louder wheeze (good sign - more air moving)
Additive bronchodilation when combined with salbutamol
Reduces inflammation over hours - prevents relapse 4-6 hours later
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Steroids don't work immediately but prevent relapse - give early

scenario_specific_response.patient_says: Patient nods, appears slightly less anxious
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Improved oxygenation but bronchospasm remains - need bronchodilator too

salbutamol.patient_says: That's helping... I can breathe easier...
salbutamol.clinical_effect: Bronchodilation, improved air entry, louder wheeze

oxygen.patient_says: Patient nods, appears slightly less anxious

hydrocortisone.clinical_effect: Reduces inflammation over hours - prevents relapse

5min.description: Patient worsening, more exhausted, increased distress, speaking only single words now

9min.description: Severe exhaustion, confusion developing, silent chest, barely able to speak, cyanotic

13min.description: Respiratory failure - bradypnea from exhaustion, bradycardia from hypoxia, requires immediate BVM ventilation

critical_harm.name: apaurin
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Respiratory depressant in patient with respiratory failure

if_given.patient_response: Patient becomes drowsy, breathing slows further, oxygen level plummets. The benzodiazepine has suppressed her already-failing respiratory drive.
if_given.clinical_note: Benzodiazepine causes respiratory depression. Critical medication error.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Never give respiratory depressants to patients in respiratory failure.

critical_harm.name: morphin
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Opioid respiratory depression, histamine release worsens bronchospasm

if_given.patient_response: Breathing becomes dangerously slow. Patient drowsy. Bronchospasm may worsen from histamine release.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Opioids are contraindicated in asthma - respiratory depression AND histamine-induced bronchospasm.

worsens.name: metoprolol
worsens.why_wrong: Beta blockers cause bronchospasm - contraindicated in asthma

if_given.patient_response: Patient's breathing worsens. Airways tighten further.

worsens.teaching_point: Beta blockers are CONTRAINDICATED in asthma. They block beta-2 receptors needed for bronchodilation.

worsens.name: furosemid
worsens.why_wrong: Wrong pathology - this is asthma (bronchospasm) not pulmonary edema
worsens.teaching_point: ASTHMA = bronchospasm (wheeze). PULMONARY EDEMA = fluid (crackles). Different pathology, different treatment.

neutral.name: glucose
neutral.teaching_point: Focus on the respiratory problem. Glucose is for hypoglycemia.

appropriate_advanced.name: magnesium_sulfate
appropriate_advanced.primary_indication: Severe/life-threatening asthma refractory to initial treatment
appropriate_advanced.teaching_point: Magnesium is appropriate for severe asthma not responding to first-line treatment. Give after salbutamol and steroids.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Bronchospasm persists, respiratory failure progresses, patient requires intubation or experiences respiratory arrest. Without bronchodilation, this patient cannot move air and will die.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Salbutamol is the first-line, life-saving treatment for acute asthma. Steroids help long-term but don't work immediately. Oxygen alone doesn't fix bronchospasm. Without a bronchodilator, this patient's airways remain constricted and respiratory failure is inevitable.

detection_criteria.condition: medication_given == 'diazepam' OR medication_given == 'midazolam' OR medication_given == 'morphine' OR medication_given == 'fentanyl'

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Respiratory drive suppressed, hypoventilation worsens, CO2 retention accelerates, respiratory arrest imminent. Sedatives in severe asthma are potentially fatal.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Sedatives and opioids are absolutely contraindicated in severe asthma. They suppress respiratory drive at a time when the patient needs maximal respiratory effort to overcome airway resistance. This error causes respiratory arrest.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Beta-blockade causes bronchospasm, directly worsening asthma. Counters the effect of salbutamol (beta-agonist). Critical deterioration.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Beta-blockers cause bronchospasm and are contraindicated in asthma. They also block the therapeutic effect of salbutamol (a beta-agonist bronchodilator). This is a dangerous medication error.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Allergic reaction on top of existing respiratory emergency
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Always verify allergies before medication administration. Patient history was available and clear.

initial.description: Severe asthma exacerbation - unable to complete sentences, accessory muscle use, tripod positioning, SpO2 88%, audible wheeze. Patient conscious but in severe respiratory distress.

early_deteriorating.description: Worsening respiratory distress - speech limited to single words, increasing work of breathing, SpO2 declining further, fatigue beginning

deteriorating.description: Severe deterioration - minimal air movement (silent chest developing), exhaustion, altered mental status, profound hypoxia

critical.description: Imminent respiratory failure - silent chest, minimal respiratory effort, severely altered consciousness, pre-arrest state

improving.description: Positive response to salbutamol - wheeze audible again (air moving), breathing easier, able to speak in phrases, SpO2 rising

stable.description: Stabilized - breathing comfortably, speaking in full sentences, SpO2 >92%, wheeze diminished or absent

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Identifies SpO2 <92%, can't complete sentences, severe distress

exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent recognition - you immediately identified this as life-threatening asthma based on inability to speak, accessory muscle use, tripod positioning, and SpO2 88%. This rapid assessment enabled immediate bronchodilator therapy.

competent.feedback_template: Good recognition of life-threatening asthma. You identified the severity indicators and proceeded with appropriate treatment.

developing.feedback_template: Recognition of asthma severity was delayed. By the time you identified it as life-threatening, the patient was in {patient_state_at_action} state with silent chest developing (sign of imminent respiratory failure). What clinical findings would have alerted you earlier?

criteria: Did not identify need for aggressive treatment
novice.feedback_template: The life-threatening nature of this asthma was not recognized. Patient had classic signs: unable to speak in sentences, tripod position, accessory muscle use, SpO2 88%. This is respiratory failure in progress and requires immediate bronchodilator therapy.

exemplary.outcome_description: Oxygen applied immediately to support severe hypoxia
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent - oxygen applied immediately to address SpO2 of 88%. This prevented further hypoxic injury while preparing bronchodilator therapy.

competent.feedback_template: Good oxygen therapy. Hypoxia was addressed before critical deterioration.

developing.feedback_template: Oxygen was delayed until patient had severe hypoxia. SpO2 88% is a critical value requiring immediate supplemental oxygen.

exemplary.outcome_description: Bronchodilator given early, prevented respiratory failure
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent timing - salbutamol nebulizer given while patient was still in initial state. You prevented progression to silent chest and respiratory failure. The patient responded well with improved air movement and rising SpO2. This is optimal asthma management.

competent.outcome_description: Bronchodilator given before critical deterioration, patient improved
competent.feedback_template: Effective treatment - salbutamol administered and patient responded with improved bronchodilation. Some worsening occurred but you intervened before silent chest developed.

developing.outcome_description: Bronchodilator delayed until near respiratory failure
developing.feedback_template: Salbutamol was delayed until patient reached {patient_state_at_action} state with silent chest developing - this is imminent respiratory failure. While treatment eventually worked, the delay allowed preventable deterioration toward respiratory arrest. In severe asthma, early bronchodilators prevent the need for intubation. What delayed the decision to give salbutamol?

criteria: Wrong medication given instead (steroids only, oxygen only)
novice.outcome_description: Critical treatment omitted or patient reached arrest
novice.feedback_template: This is addressed as a Safety Gate issue - salbutamol is the first-line, life-saving treatment for severe asthma. Without bronchodilation, this patient will progress to respiratory failure.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Check vitals after treatment, reassess breathing

common_errors.teaching_point: Salbutamol must be given within 5 minutes for life-threatening asthma
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Time is tissue—every minute of bronchospasm compounds hypoxic damage that can't be undone.

common_errors.teaching_point: SpO2 88% is critically low - brain cells die below 90%
common_errors.clinical_anchor: At 88% saturation, her brain is starving. Oxygen isn't comfort—it's survival.

common_errors.teaching_point: Steroids prevent relapse 4-6 hours later - give early despite delayed effect
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Salbutamol treats NOW. Steroids treat 4 HOURS FROM NOW. Give both.

common_errors.teaching_point: ABCDE assessment prevents missing critical findings like silent chest
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Systematic assessment isn't bureaucracy—it's how you find the silent chest that kills.

common_errors.teaching_point: Silent chest = severe bronchospasm with minimal air movement = pre-arrest
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Wheeze means air moving—concerning but alive. Silence means no air moving—minutes from arrest.
Vague orders create vague outcomes. Precision in orders creates precision in care.
Treatment without reassessment is like throwing medication into a void—you never know if it landed.

consequence_templates.template: You applied oxygen at {actual_time} minutes (target: {target_time} minutes). During the {delay_minutes} minute delay, {patient_name}'s brain was receiving inadequate oxygen. SpO2 of {initial_spo2}% means brain cells were hypoxic. Every minute of delay at this saturation level causes cumulative neuronal stress that compounds recovery time.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Brain tissue begins suffering hypoxic injury below SpO2 90%. Prolonged hypoxia leads to cognitive impairment, increased risk of respiratory arrest, and longer recovery times.

consequence_templates.template: Oxygen was never applied. {patient_name} remained critically hypoxic (SpO2 {initial_spo2}%) throughout your contact. This represents a fundamental failure to address the most immediate life threat. Brain cells begin dying within minutes at this saturation level.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Failure to address critical hypoxia is a life-threatening omission. SpO2 88% indicates severe hypoxemia requiring immediate intervention.

consequence_templates.template: Salbutamol was given at {actual_time} minutes (target: {target_time} minutes). During the {delay_minutes} minute delay, {patient_name}'s bronchospasm continued unopposed. Her airways remained critically constricted, work of breathing remained exhausting, and respiratory failure risk increased with each passing minute.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Bronchospasm in severe asthma is progressive. Delayed bronchodilator therapy allows continued airway inflammation, mucus plugging, and respiratory muscle fatigue.

consequence_templates.template: No bronchodilator was given. {patient_name} had life-threatening asthma with severe bronchospasm, yet the primary treatment was never administered. Without bronchodilation, her airways remained critically narrowed, making respiratory failure inevitable.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Failure to administer bronchodilator in life-threatening asthma is a critical omission. Salbutamol is the definitive treatment for bronchospasm.

critical_decision_points.description: Balancing systematic assessment with treatment urgency in life-threatening respiratory distress
optimal_sequence: Rapid recognition of life-threatening features (SpO2 88%, tripod position, can't speak sentences)
Quick focused assessment (30 seconds, not 5 minutes)
Reassessment after treatment to confirm effect

scoring.optimal: Recognized life-threatening asthma within 60 seconds, gave oxygen and bronchodilator within 3-5 minutes while continuing assessment. Demonstrated 'treat and assess simultaneously' approach.
scoring.acceptable: Gave bronchodilator within 5 minutes, completed assessment afterward. Got critical treatment in reasonable time.
scoring.suboptimal: Delayed treatment >7 minutes while completing full assessment. Over-prioritized assessment over urgent treatment.
scoring.dangerous: Delayed critical treatment >10 minutes OR never gave bronchodilator OR gave contraindicated medication.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: In life-threatening asthma, you have 30 seconds to assess severity and 5 minutes to treat. Assessment and treatment run in parallel, not series.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Life-threatening asthma requires immediate intervention. A 30-second focused assessment (SpO2, speaking ability, work of breathing) tells you everything you need to start treatment. Full SAMPLE history can be obtained WHILE nebulizer is running.

critical_decision_points.description: Choosing appropriate oxygen delivery for severity of hypoxia
optimal_sequence: Select high-flow device (NRB 15L or nebulizer-driven oxygen)

scoring.optimal: Specified NRB at 15L/min or oxygen-driven nebulizer, stated target 94-98%, applied within 2 minutes.
scoring.acceptable: Applied high-flow oxygen quickly, even if device not initially specified.
scoring.suboptimal: Vague order ('give oxygen') or chose low-flow device (nasal cannula) for critical hypoxia.
scoring.dangerous: Did not give oxygen despite SpO2 88% OR delayed >5 minutes.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: SpO2 88% means brain hypoxia NOW. Match your oxygen delivery to the severity—nasal cannula won't cut it.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Device must match severity. SpO2 88% requires 15L NRB or nebulizer-driven oxygen. Nasal cannula (1-6L) is grossly inadequate for this severity.

critical_decision_points.description: Identifying silent chest as ominous pre-arrest sign

scoring.optimal: Identified silent chest, recognized as pre-arrest sign, escalated urgency, prepared BVM.
scoring.acceptable: Noticed decreased air entry, showed appropriate concern, escalated interventions.
scoring.suboptimal: Heard decreased air entry but didn't recognize significance.
scoring.dangerous: Interpreted silent chest as improvement ('she's calming down').

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Wheeze means air moving—concerning but alive. Silence means no air moving—minutes from arrest.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Silent chest is THE most ominous finding in asthma. It means airways are so constricted that almost no air moves. Paradoxically, LOUDER wheeze after treatment is GOOD (more air moving).

key_concepts: Life-threatening asthma features: SpO2 <92%, exhaustion, silent chest, can't speak sentences
Treatment sequence: Oxygen + Salbutamol FIRST (within 5 min), then Steroids
Silent chest = ominous pre-arrest sign, NOT improvement
Steroids prevent relapse - give early despite 60-minute onset
clinical_pearls: Speaking in words only (not phrases) = severe respiratory distress
Tripod position = patient maximizing accessory muscle use
Louder wheeze after bronchodilator = GOOD sign (more air moving)
RR >30 + SpO2 <92% + can't speak = life-threatening triad
